cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.CV, cs.CL, cs.CR 

This paper is likely to belong to the sub-category of machine learning (cs.LG) as it addresses the problem of learning a binary classifier. It also involves the use of ensembles of classifiers, which is a common technique in machine learning. Additionally, the paper mentions the use of loss functions, which are a fundamental concept in machine learning. 

The paper may also belong to the sub-category of artificial intelligence (cs.AI) as it involves the development of a classifier that can make decisions about when to abstain from making a prediction. This is a problem that is relevant to many applications of AI, such as autonomous systems and decision-making. 

The paper may also be relevant to the sub-category of computer vision (cs.CV) as it involves the use of classifiers to make predictions about unlabeled data. This is a common problem in computer vision, where large amounts of unlabeled data are often available. 

The paper may also be relevant to the sub-category of computational linguistics (cs.CL) as it mentions the use of ensembles of "specialist" classifiers. This is a technique that is commonly used in natural language processing, where different classifiers may be trained to handle different aspects of language. 

Finally, the paper may be relevant to the sub-category of cryptography and security (cs.CR) as it mentions the development of a minimax optimal algorithm. This is a concept that is often used in cryptography
